instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message: Ok so I have a liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> it’s been worked on previously as I found out further into working on it. It starts with a charged battery but with a charger will get green light but power cycling with fan spin and green light going off then coming back on and fan spin/green light. I’ve tried replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and have checked <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> at <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> and get 20 ohms, <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> are also correct. Anyone have any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Steady voltage at F6905 with charger alone (no battery)?
If not, check with fake charger, or lab PSU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message: I'll check now. Genuine charger though I've used it with other laptops as its my own so quite sure its not the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message: The mentioned test is necesarry to detect an input leakage issue (on MLB), not charger problem!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Ok done 16.6v stable when greenlight and fans spinning then 16.9v when greenlight goes off. 
Couple of other things I just ran ASD and fails the sleep test, ASD gives error 'no override file detected, please flash before running diagnostics'.  
Also no serial number when osx is loaded so bios has been messed with.
I know it should be C02HLDP0DV33 according to the logic board sticker and box.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Good BIOS already posted somewhere on the forum.
Take this, if you cannot find it.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/11vG3JfnmrDxf82O2E2vjHnXUCAjuPFpI/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
Check <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 voltages, when no Magsafe light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Thanks flashed that no difference though.

<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
1 3.42
2 0
3 0v
4 2.86v
5 2.83v off 2.85v on

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>
1 2.33v
2 2,33v
3 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Try another DCIN board and charger.
Check again <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>.
When is enabled, pins 4/5 must have the same level.
Did you change DCIN small board???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message: I think theres some gunk in that area dont know how i measured 2.83v twice but im 0.25v on some blank areas around it so have used my ultrasonic toothbrush and getting a clean 3.41v. same symptons

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Still not steady light on Magsafe?
If yes, then reball SMC; if <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Not a steady light on the lite on which after checking has an aftermarket cable but is on the delta, my 858d would kill a smc in my opinion I have to run at max temp to get macbook parts to move anyway.

If SMC is the only option I'll have to leave this just think its weird it works on battery not charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling on magsafe
threads.message:
Be aware this board requires 85W charger to start without battery.
However it should work with battery and even 45W charger connected.
A bad DCIN board can block battery charging.
SMC will not charge the battery, if cannot communicate properly with 1-wire memory from Magsafe cable.
